writers.name: Ralph Waldo Emerson
writers.description: American essayist, leaturer, philosopher and poet who led the transcendentalist movement of the mid-19 th century. He was seen as a champion of individualism and a prescient critic of countervailing pressures of society.

writers.name: Mark Twain
writers.description: Samuel Langhorne Clemens, better known by his pen name Mark Twain, was an American writer, humorist, entrepreneur, publisher, and lecturer. Among his novels are The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and its sequel, the Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, the latter often called

writers.name: William Shakespeare
writers.description: William Shakespeare was an English poet, playwright and actor, widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language and the world's greatest dramatist. He is often called England's national poet and the 'Bard of Avon'

writers.name: Friedrich Nietzsche
writers.description: German philosopher, cultural critic, composer, poet, philologist, and Latin and Greek scholar. His thought enjoyed renewed popularity in the 1960s, and his ideas have since had a profound impact on 20th and early-21st century thinkers across philosophy—especially in schools of continental philosophy such as existentialism, postmodernism and post-structuralism—as well as art, literature, psychology, politics, and popular culture.

texts.title: Self-Reliance
texts.description: An essay that contains the most thorough statement of one of Emerson's recurrent themes: the need for each individual to avoid conformity and false consistency, and follow their own instincts and ideas.

texts.title: Nature
texts.description: An essay that puts forth the foundation of transcendentalism, a belief system that espouses a non-traditional appreciation of nature.

texts.title: Thus Spoke Zarathustra
texts.description: A philosophical novel that deals with ideas such as the "eternal recurrence of the same", the parable on the "death of God", and the "prophecy" of the Übermensch.

texts.title: Beyond Good and Evil
texts.description: A book that expands the ideas of his previous work, Thus Spoke Zarathustra, with a more critical and polemical approach.

texts.title: The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious
texts.description: Part 1 of Volume 9 in The Collected Works of C. G. Jung, a series of books published by Princeton University Press in the U.S. and Routledge & Kegan Paul in the U.K.

texts.title: Memories, Dreams, Reflections
texts.description: An autobiographical book by Swiss psychologist Carl Jung and an associate, Aniela Jaffé.

texts.title: The Hero with a Thousand Faces
texts.description: A work of comparative mythology by American mythologist Joseph Campbell, in which he discusses his theory of the journey of the archetypal hero found in world mythologies.

texts.title: The Power of Myth
texts.description: A book based on the 1988 PBS documentary Joseph Campbell and the Power of Myth.

texts.title: The Book of Secrets: 112 Meditations to Discover the Mystery Within
texts.description: In this comprehensive and practical guide, the secrets of the ancient science of Tantra become available to a contemporary audience for the first time.

texts.title: Love, Freedom, Aloneness: The Koan of Relationships
